channel.title: Music team or whatever
channel.description:
Let's make some music! Post your instrument, years of experience and your genre! We can do some individual playing on it, send it to someone with a good music program and and put it together to see if we have any talent!!
Me: Guitar 4 Classic rock, metal, metalcore. Will be open to other things, however.

item.title: Music team or whatever
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“blakeman8192, post:21, topic:416338”][quote author=Java Is My Bitch link=topic=518266.msg3766139#msg3766139 date=1317251030]

Drums, several years, heavy metal.

I also have professional recording and audio mixing equipment.
[/quote]Can you program a drum machine unit? I’m not that great with drums. I’d prefer that the drums are digital for a heavier kick.

I can but I wont, it’s a disgrace haha. I just mic up my drums, take the recording to a metronome, then mix it (compression, noise gates, EQing) until you take out all of the background noise and it sounds professional. Drum machines are for assholes.

This is me playing, back when I had no idea how to edit and mix drum recordings.

It’s not so bad quality, and I can make current recordings a lot better.[/quote]Compression?? Shame on you! Compression ruins music.

So neways, Guitar for 12 years, primarily heavy metal and hard rock/blues.

Rough unmixed recording done after a year of hiatus:

Read full topic

item.title: Music team or whatever
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Guitar - 6 years, anything from heavy metal to red hot chili’s.
Drums - 4 years, pretty much the same

Also, about the recording, you can just use a jack lead from the amp line out directly into the line in on your sound card or laptop, you then go to line in sound options and make sure you tick the box that says something like ‘listen to this device’, you can then just use windows sound recorder if you like, works as good as any other software and providing you use the right volume etc it’ll be crystal clear. js.

Read full topic

item.title: Music team or whatever
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I’m sure a topic like this has already been created but it simply never took off.
I can play guitar so I might record something terrible and upload

ps, it’s best if you have a set song and actually allocate instruments to the appropriate people first, then do all the recording.

Read full topic

item.title: Music team or whatever
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

[quote=“Java Is My Bitch, post:22, topic:416338”][quote author=blakeman8192 link=topic=518266.msg3766145#msg3766145 date=1317251177]

[quote author=Java Is My Bitch link=topic=518266.msg3766139#msg3766139 date=1317251030]

Drums, several years, heavy metal.

I also have professional recording and audio mixing equipment.
[/quote]Can you program a drum machine unit? I’m not that great with drums. I’d prefer that the drums are digital for a heavier kick.

I can but I wont, it’s a disgrace haha. I just mic up my drums, take the recording to a metronome, then mix it (compression, noise gates, EQing) until you take out all of the background noise and it sounds professional. Drum machines are for assholes.

This is me playing, back when I had no idea how to edit and mix drum recordings.

It’s not so bad quality, and I can make current recordings a lot better.
[/quote]Great, but I’d like to have a sidechained synthesizer as well. So maybe you can just do the snares, highhats, etc live and then the kick drum digitally? [/quote]

NOPE

Read full topic

[/quote]Can you program a drum machine unit? I’m not that great with drums. I’d prefer that the drums are digital for a heavier kick.

I can but I wont, it’s a disgrace haha. I just mic up my drums, take the recording to a metronome, then mix it (compression, noise gates, EQing) until you take out all of the background noise and it sounds professional. Drum machines are for assholes.

[quote=“Java Is My Bitch, post:20, topic:416338”][quote author=blakeman8192 link=topic=518266.msg3766120#msg3766120 date=1317250573]
Drums, several years, heavy metal.

I also have professional recording and audio mixing equipment.
[/quote]Can you program a drum machine unit? I’m not that great with drums. I’d prefer that the drums are digital for a heavier kick.[/quote]

I can but I wont, it’s a disgrace haha. I just mic up my drums, take the recording to a metronome, then mix it (compression, noise gates, EQing) until you take out all of the background noise and it sounds professional. Drum machines are for assholes.

This is me playing, back when I had no idea how to edit and mix drum recordings.

It’s not so bad quality, and I can make current recordings a lot better.
